I have an activity and a bunch of fragments attached to that activity. In the activity I have an onactivityresult method. I also have an onactivityresult method in one of my fragments. I’m having a problem that when I launch an activity from a fragment (in this case, it’s the facebook login activity launched by clicking the login with facebook button) it doesn’t return to the onactivityresult method in the fragment, rather it returns to the onactivity result method in the parent activity. If I comment out the onactivityresult method in the activity, then it does come back to the onactivityresult method in the fragment. How do I make it so that the onactivityresult in the fragment gets called instead of the onactivityresult in the activity?
<@U1T440H8V|david.coronel> has joined the channel
<@U1PPDV4SD>: call it from the parent manually? Did you also call the parent method in the activity's onresult?
<@U061HDV96>: what do you mean call the parent method?
Call the super method in the activity's on result.
Because if it works when you comment it out, it falls back to the super method which apparently triggers the fragments so calling that before your custom code in on result should work.
ok let me try that
<@U1PPDV4SD> make sure you're calling `startActivityForResult` method of your fragment and not `getActivity().startActivityForResult`
and yeah also make sure you defer to the superclass implementation of onActivityResult, otherwise the result won't get back to your fragment
<@U061HDV96>: shit, that worked! Thank you so much! I spent hours trying to figure out why it wasn’t working.
<@U061HDV96>: Could you explain why I had to call super in the activities’ onactivityresult in order to trigger the fragment’s onactivityresult method?
<https://androidchat.slack.com/archives/beginners/p1468948612000062>

attachments.fallback: [July 19th, 2016 10:16 AM] andreasbackx: Because if it works when you comment it out, it falls back to the super method which apparently triggers the fragments so calling that before your custom code in on result should work.
attachments.text: Because if it works when you comment it out, it falls back to the super method which apparently triggers the fragments so calling that before your custom code in on result should work.

text: I don't know what else I can explain to you.
If you want to know how they do it, best look at the source of onActivityResult

<@U061HDV96>: I guess what is confusing me is that I thought super was used to call the current class' parent method. So if A extends B, and in some method in the class A I call super.onCreate(), this would mean that I would run the onCreate method from class B. But in this case, my activity is only extending AppCompactActivity. So then, how does it know to call the correct fragment just by using super?
<@U1PPDV4SD>: fragments are in an activity. FragmentManager holds the fragments iirc.
<@U0546QERR>: thanks, yeah I was not using getactivity().startactivityforresult
<@U1PPDV4SD>: <https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Fragment.html#onAttach(android.app.Activity)>
AppCompatActivity is a FragmentActivity, those Activities know about the fragment manager and can forward the results

<@U0546QERR>: ah ok, I see. Is it always the case that when I’m in a fragment and I begin another activity and then that activity finishes, will it always go back to the startactivityforresult method of the current activity?

yeah if you used `startActivityForResult` it will callback to `onActivityResult` for the Activity. the call to `super.onActivityResult` will trickle up to the implementation in FragmentActivity (i think) which knows to forward the result to your Fragment, if you called `startActivityForResult` from the fragment
that's why the call to `super` is important
if you put a breakpoint in the source for `startActivityForResult` you can step through and see how it works, it does some clever math with the request code
<@U0546QERR>: cool, that makes sense. I will try that, thanks for your help!
